name: throb
content:
Add to word list
Add to word list
to produce a strong, regular beat: The sound hits you like a wave and the bass throbs.
If a part of your body throbs, you feel pain in it in a series of regular beats: His head throbbed, and his body ached.
Thesaurus: synonyms, antonyms, and examples
to cause painhurtMy leg hurts.acheMy legs are still aching from my run yesterday.throbMy head throbbed.stingHis cheeks stung from the aftershave he'd just put on.smartThe smoke was thick, making her eyes smart.rubThe clothing is cleverly stitched to prevent the seams rubbing anywhere.

You can also find related words, phrases, and synonyms in the topics:
Pain & painful
a strong, regular beat: the throb of the engine
pain that is felt as a series of regular beats: Tablets had faded his headache to a dull throb.
Thesaurus: synonyms, antonyms, and examples
painpainThere are drugs you can take to ease the pain.agonyMothers will often talk about the agony of childbirth.sorenessIf you sailed through the exercises without soreness, you can move on.acheI developed a dull ache in my jaw.discomfortSometimes receding gums can cause discomfort.stingBee stings can cause an allergic reaction in some people.

More examplesFewer examplesWe could hear the distant throb of dance music.At weekends our house was full of the throb of the washing machine.There was a constant throb from the blister.He felt throbs of pain in his arthritic knee.

to produce a regular, forceful beat: His head throbbed with pain. throb noun [ C/U ] us
Your browser doesn't support HTML5 audio
/θrɑb/
[ U ] We could feel the throb of the music from the party upstairs.
